parts.instructions: You are going to read an article about urban planning. For questions 1-6, choose the answer (A, B, C or D) which you think fits best according to the text.

passage.title: Designing Cities for the Future
passage.content:
Ana Rodriguez surveyed the construction site that would soon become Riverside District's first vertical forest - a residential building where every balcony would be covered with trees and plants. As the city's chief urban planner, she had spent five years developing this innovative approach to urban housing.

'Traditional city planning focused on separating different functions - housing here, shops there, offices somewhere else,' Ana explained to her colleague Miguel Santos. 'But modern cities need integration. People want to live, work, and socialize in the same neighborhoods.'

The vertical forest project exemplified this new philosophy. The building would house 200 families while also featuring ground-floor shops, a community center, and rooftop gardens where residents could grow their own food. The integrated plant systems would purify air, reduce noise pollution, and provide natural cooling.

However, convincing city council members to approve such experimental designs had required extensive research and community consultation. 'Politicians are naturally cautious,' Ana noted. 'They need to see evidence that new approaches will actually benefit residents.'

Ana's team had studied similar projects in cities across Europe and Asia, documenting their environmental and social impacts. The research showed that green buildings significantly improved residents' mental health and created stronger community bonds. 'When people have access to nature and communal spaces, they're more likely to know their neighbors and participate in local activities,' she observed.

The financial benefits were equally compelling. Energy costs for green buildings were typically 30-40% lower than conventional structures, and property values in neighborhoods with integrated green spaces appreciated faster than in traditional developments.

Looking ahead, Ana envisioned transforming entire districts using these principles. 'We're not just building individual green buildings,' she emphasized. 'We're creating interconnected networks of sustainable spaces that will make the whole city more livable.'

The project had attracted international attention, with delegations from other cities visiting to learn about Riverside's approach. Ana welcomed this interest but stressed that successful urban planning must always reflect local conditions and community needs. 'What works here might not work elsewhere,' she concluded. 'Good design emerges from understanding the specific challenges and opportunities of each place.'

questions.text: What distinguishes Ana's vertical forest project from traditional urban housing?
options: A) It houses more families in less space.
B) It integrates multiple functions in one location.
C) It costs less to build than conventional buildings.
D) It uses entirely renewable energy sources.

questions.text: Why did Ana need to provide extensive research to city council members?
options: A) They questioned the project's environmental benefits.
B) They were unfamiliar with green building techniques.
C) They were cautious about approving experimental designs.
D) They preferred traditional architectural styles.

questions.text: What social benefit did Ana's research reveal about green buildings?
options: A) Residents exercise more frequently.
B) Property maintenance costs decrease.
C) Community connections strengthen.
D) Crime rates drop significantly.

questions.text: According to the article, what financial advantage do green buildings offer?
options: A) Construction costs are lower.
B) Insurance premiums are reduced.
C) Maintenance requirements decrease.
D) Energy expenses are significantly reduced.

questions.text: What is Ana's long-term vision for urban development?
options: A) Building taller structures to house more people.
B) Creating connected networks of sustainable spaces.
C) Replacing all traditional buildings with green alternatives.
D) Limiting urban growth to preserve natural areas.

questions.text: What does Ana emphasize about successful urban planning?
options: A) It should follow international standards.
B) It must prioritize environmental concerns.
C) It requires significant government investment.
D) It must reflect local conditions and needs.

parts.instructions: You are going to read an article about social media's impact on communication. Six paragraphs have been removed from the article. Choose from the paragraphs A-G the one which fits each gap (7-12). There is one extra paragraph which you do not need to use.

passage.title: The Evolution of Digital Communication
passage.content:
Social media platforms have fundamentally changed how people connect, share information, and maintain relationships. These changes have created both opportunities and challenges for personal and professional communication.

[7]

The speed of digital communication has created new expectations for response times. Many people now expect immediate replies to messages, leading to increased stress and anxiety when responses are delayed.

[8]

Visual communication has become increasingly important in the digital age. Images, videos, and emojis now convey emotions and information that were previously expressed through spoken or written words.

[9]

The global reach of social media has enabled unprecedented cultural exchange. People can now easily connect with others from different countries and backgrounds, leading to greater understanding and collaboration.

[10]

However, the permanence of digital communication creates new challenges. Posts, comments, and messages can be archived and searched indefinitely, making privacy and reputation management more complex.

[11]

Professional networking has been transformed by digital platforms. Career opportunities, business partnerships, and professional relationships often develop through online connections rather than traditional face-to-face meetings.

[12]

As digital communication continues to evolve, society must find ways to harness its benefits while addressing its potential negative impacts on mental health and authentic human connection.

paragraphs.text: This shift has particularly affected younger generations, who have developed sophisticated visual literacy skills that older generations may struggle to understand.
Traditional letter-writing and phone conversations have largely been replaced by instant messaging, email, and social media interactions.
This constant connectivity can blur the boundaries between personal and professional time, making it difficult to disconnect from work or social obligations.
These cross-cultural connections have led to increased awareness of global issues and collaborative solutions to international challenges.
This has created new concerns about digital footprints and the long-term consequences of online behavior.
These platforms have democratized professional networking, allowing people to build careers regardless of their geographic location or traditional social connections.
Many employers now use social media to screen potential employees, making online presence a crucial factor in career development.

parts.instructions: You are going to read about four people who work in specialized fields. For questions 13-22, choose from the people (A-D). The people may be chosen more than once.

people.name: Dr. Elena Vasquez - Marine Biologist
people.text: I study deep-sea ecosystems that most people will never see. My research takes me to some of the most remote locations on Earth, using specialized submarines to explore ocean depths where sunlight has never penetrated. The pressure at these depths would instantly crush a human body, so we rely entirely on technology to observe and collect samples. Many of the species I study are completely unknown to science - we estimate that 80% of deep-ocean life remains undiscovered. The work is expensive and logistically challenging, but these ecosystems may hold keys to understanding life's origins and developing new medicines. Climate change is affecting even these remote environments, making our research increasingly urgent.

people.name: Carlos Montenegro - Forensic Accountant
people.text: I investigate financial crimes by analyzing complex accounting records and digital transactions. My work combines traditional auditing skills with detective work, following money trails that can span multiple countries and involve sophisticated schemes to hide illegal activities. The cases I work on range from corporate fraud to money laundering for organized crime. Attention to detail is crucial - a single overlooked transaction can mean the difference between conviction and acquittal. I often testify in court, translating complex financial evidence into terms that judges and juries can understand. The work can be stressful, especially when dealing with high-stakes cases, but there's satisfaction in helping bring financial criminals to justice.

people.name: Maya Patel - Voice Actor
people.text: I bring animated characters to life through voice work for films, television shows, and video games. People often think voice acting is easy because you don't have to memorize lines or worry about physical appearance, but it requires incredible vocal control and emotional range. I can spend hours in recording studios, repeating lines until they perfectly match the character's personality and the scene's mood. Each character demands a unique voice, accent, and speaking pattern - I might voice a wise elderly wizard in the morning and an energetic child character in the afternoon. The industry is highly competitive, and steady work requires building relationships with directors, producers, and casting agents. Technology has made home recording possible, but professional studio work still produces the highest quality results.

people.name: Roberto Silva - Perfume Designer
people.text: I create custom fragrances for luxury brands and individual clients by combining hundreds of different scent components. My 'nose' - the industry term for someone with exceptional scent perception - was developed through years of training and practice. I can identify thousands of individual scents and predict how they will interact when combined. Creating a new perfume typically takes six months to two years, involving countless iterations and adjustments. The work requires both artistic creativity and scientific precision - understanding the molecular structure of aromatic compounds is as important as having an aesthetic vision. Market trends influence my work, but truly successful fragrances often break conventional rules and create entirely new scent categories.
